description: Tree works subject to a tree preservation order
decision_conditions:
Refusal of permission
The application to fell the tree has been refused for three reasons:
(i)	on the basis of loss of a visual amenity and 
(ii)	on the basis that the agent has failed to supply sufficient evidence to satisfy the Council that the tree requires removal. 
(iii)	The agent has failed to provide a structural engineers report and level monitoring to discount other probable causes of the damage, damaged or leaking drains and the change of soil beneath the property from London Clay to River bed gravel. 

Loss of visual amenity

The tree contributes materially to the amenities of the locality, playing an important part in providing a sense of scale, maturity and textural diversity to the immediate vicinity.

The tree is situated within the Canonbury Conservation area and the council deemed this tree worthy of the implication of a TPO in 2007. The level of amenity provided since the imposition of the TPO has not declined.
    

Level of evidence

We do not currently have the level of evidence we require to allow this tree to be removed, the level of evidence and detail required being commensurate with the amenity value of the tree. In this particular case taking a balanced view the Council considers that the evidence so far presented does not meet the tests Islington Council consider appropriate in considering the removal of this preserved tree. 

Specifically we have not been supplied with a structural engineers report or any level monitoring.

A structural engineers report detailing the type of property and extent and location of all the property damage, this must contain a BRE Digest 251 assessment of the damage. In addition the report should mention any recent building modifications including history if applicable.

There is reference to a report by Michael Mercer of Chester & Partners discussing the damage. This report has not been submitted in support of the application.

We will require Detail of the nature and estimated cost of options to repair the damage if the tree is removed and if the tree remains. Without an estimation of this the council cannot make an informed decision as to the relative value of the tree against the cost of repair options.

We do require the measurement of the extent and distribution of vertical movement using level monitoring.  For us to consider the removal of a TPO tree the data provided must be sufficient to show a pattern of movement consistent with the presence of the implicated tree.

Drainage issues have been identified and are awaiting repairs. It is possible where we have such a high level of coarse fines that structural damage may be caused by the washing of fines from the soil by leaking drains. Prolonged exposure to leaking foul water drains or grey water irrigation into clay soil can therefore cause damage to overlying structures. The induced chemical consolidation can be equivalent to significant desiccation over time.

We would expect the monitoring after the drainage repairs to identify if this is a contributory factor. 

The trial pits indicate different soil profiles; this could also be a contributory factor in any differential movement of the property.

We do not currently have the level of evidence we require to allow us to make an informed decision as to whether this important amenity tree should be removed. Without the structural engineers report and the level monitoring the council cannot reasonably permit the removal of this protected tree. Further investigation is appropriate and the council remains open to further application with this evidence.
